body.p:
I duly acknowledge
your last 2 letters, and the receipt of
Occidents and 3 copies of the printed
Edition of the Pentateuch. You must
like all good and loyal citizens of the
great Republic, submit to the difficulties
of the present situation. When so much
paper is required for Green Backs and
other numerous varieties of notes, issued
for the maintenance of public credit, the
Editor of the Occident should not grumble
at the rise in price of printing material.
Sacrifices are indispensable on the part
of every individual when so glorious a war
for the redemption and freedom of the negro
race, and the subjugation of white rebels
is to be brought to a triumphant close.

When that object is accomplished, your self
denial, tho' it may involve you in pecuniary
losses, will be appreciated; and congress, when
personally appealed to, will, doubtless, especially
the republican part of it, recompense you with
a grant from the public treasury. Your petition
cannot fail of being signed by all the Jewish
population throughout the States, and public
virtue will thus meet its own reward. I have
not yet had time to peruse the article to which
you direct my attention. My time is so occupied
with my school, owing to the Shamash of the
Congregation; my assistant Hebrew teacher,
having left for California, that I have had no
leisure. Our new minister, Mr. Myers, has got
himself into a dilemma with some of the big
wigs of the Synagogue, in consequence of his
many refusal to sanction the calling up to
the Sepher, of people married to Christian women,
and colored women to boot. You can have no
conception of the falling off in this particular congre-
gation from various causes within the last twenty
years. Its numerous members have dwindled down
to a mere handfull; but the pride and arrogance
remain as of old; and tincture all their acts, to
which had feelings, towards all who venture to differ
from the rulers in opinion, largely add their share.
As for the minister of the other Synagogue, De?
the least I say of him the better. I am not a מלשין

work out for the Occident, if my liver permits.
Moses, it is evident could not have imposed on the
2 ? tribes the duty of going over the Jordan חמשים
but only חלוצים armed for war; and therefore he uses the
latter; whereas Joshua could, as commanded,
decline to forage for them, and compel them to manage
their own commissariat. The sacred text is not
strained to meet acord with this explanation but rather
removes the difficulty of accounting in what
way the people subsisted, until the ?
fell.

I have formed an acquaintance with
a Dr. Daniell—of the British army, a man
of wonderful knowledge in all matters relating
to Africa, where he passed 18 years of his life.
He is a great scholar, not alone in the studies
appertaining to his profession, but in others, and
is esteemed an authority in England in philology,
ethnology, botany, &c. A bosom friend of Professor
Owen the Eminent naturalist. We had a
delightful evening's talk till 12 o'Clock last
night, and that is how I spent my Purim. He
possesses monotheism, but believes in the Bible,
not I think, in the Testament.

The war, I see, continues to linger.
The termination cannot however be very
distant, and I hope it will end as I wish.

It may however become more complicated
by the defiant attitude of one of the
belligerents towards the French Emperor.
The English Government is not hypocritical.
Your charge is not just. If it had intervened,
I incline to think with Lords Palmerston
and Russel that the north would have raised
such an overwhelming force as would have
crushed the south at once אל תעמוד לפני רעך בשעת כעסו
applies as well to nations as individuals.
England has enough on her hands in meeting the
hungry cravings of her starving operatives
without putting her fingers into her neighbour's
dish. I call their neutral action wise and
humane, and it will prove to be so in the
long run. The feelings of the English government
& nation too are with the south, and the
ravings of Bright & Cobden and the anti-
slavery party are ineffectual to change them.
I am alive to the short comings of my native
country, but they are in this matter it is not
obnoxious to the abuse lavished upon it by the
people of America.

My wife and mother join with
me in affectionate wishes & regards

but I would surprise you, were I to often the
budget of doings and sayings of this man. Judaism
is in a bad state here, spirit of religion is utterly
wanting, with no one competent to rouse it from the
torpor into which it has fallen. We have had here a
certain Rabbi Alfendri from Smyrna, his mission
here was a failure; we are too poor ourselves, and
have too many indigent ones in our midst, to
contribute to the claims (?) of such travelling gentry.
Why don't they stop at home? We hear of the
doings and writings of Mr. De Solla, late of Montego
Bay, against Mr. Morais. Can't you send me some
of that precious productions? Are you not going
to use your pen in defense of scripture against
Bishop Calendo? Benisch has come out manfully,
but altho' he has answered some points admirably,
I do not like all he has written. The wood, water,
and pasture question he has handled ably. I
am, just to keep my hand in, maintaining a cor
respondence on the subject with a xtian clergyman;
and made the word חמשים the my study, at his request.
I cannot agree that it means equipped, or harnessed,
in gist, or armed, but ? think it signifies
victualled or provisioned from חמץ the abdomen.
The Bible says וגם צדה לא עשו להם; Does that imply that
they had no food at all except the בצק? I should say
that צדה means cooked or prepared provisions, and
עשו being joined to it, an act of preparation or
cooking is inferred, the same as אפה to בצק before
the latter becomes לחם. Hence the Israelites might

not have had צדה, and get the onions, leeks
garlic, and Cucumbers as vegetables, and the
melons and dates as fruits might have afforded
them a plentiful supply of food for the חמץ belly
or stomach, and hence they were חמשים. In Joshua
chap: i 11 the people are ordered הכינו לכם צדה, whilst
in verse 14 the Reub: Gad: through: are told חמושים
ואתם תעברו חמשים ye shall pass over victualled, ergo, you must
furnish your own commissarist. Again in IV.12
it is written they passed over חמשים provisioned, and in
the following verse חלוצי צבא in fighting tr?, or
armed for war. In Judges VII.II the חמשים could not
have been the armed men, or they would have been
called sentinels, patriots, or piquets, whose duty is
always בקצה המחנה; and in verse 19 they are properly
named, שמרים which you have rendered sentinels. These
חמשים must consequently have been the suttlers
whose place or station was outside the lives, and
not within them with the soldiery. If this view
can be maintained, it disposes of the objections of
those who assert that the people had no food but
the בצק. God did not lead them thro' a fertile country
like the ארץ פלשתים, but into the מדבר; yet that unpro-
ductive waste had no terrors for them, they had no
immediate fears of hunger, for they were חמשים furnished
with food, tho' not with צדה cooked food. If
rationalists must be satisfied and shown demon-
stratively that the multitude was not in a
starving condition, my exegesis will convince
them. This hasty sketch I may possibly
